faultDescr.para: Hydrogen leak detection system activated during refueling operation. H2 concentration exceeds 10 ppm threshold (25% of Lower Explosive Limit). Leak may be at receptacle connection, valve seals, or line fittings. CAOS Neural Network model NN-02-32-LEAK-v1.0.h5 provides leak source localization analysis.

symptom.para: One or more of the following symptoms:

listItem.para: Leak detection alarm activated (audible and visual)
H2 sensor reading > 10 ppm
Multiple sensors showing elevated H2 concentration
Refueling system automatically shut down
Visible venting or misting at connection points
Frost formation on components (indicates liquid H2 leak)
Unusual hissing sound near refueling equipment

warning.warningAndCautionPara: HYDROGEN LEAK - EXPLOSION HAZARD. Take immediate action to isolate leak and evacuate personnel from danger zone.

listItem.para: Press EMERGENCY STOP button (red mushroom button on refueling panel)
Verify automatic shutoff valves have closed
Evacuate all personnel to upwind location, minimum 75 meters from aircraft
Alert airport fire department immediately
Activate emergency ventilation to maximum (if safe to do so)
Establish perimeter - no entry until H2 concentration < 1% (below LEL/4)

isolationStep.para: From safe location, monitor H2 concentration on CAOS display.
Wait for H2 concentration to drop below 1% before proceeding.
This typically takes 5-15 minutes with ventilation running.

caution.warningAndCautionPara: Do NOT re-enter area until H2 concentration confirmed < 1% by TWO independent calibrated detectors.

isolationStep.para: Access CAOS system from remote terminal.
Navigate to: Diagnostics → H2 Systems → Leak Analysis
CAOS NN-02-32-LEAK-v1.0.h5 model analyzes sensor pattern to predict leak location:

listItemDefinition.para: Leak likely at refueling receptacle connection
Leak likely at main refueling valve
Leak likely at flexible hose connection
Leak likely at tank inlet connection
Major leak or multiple leak points

isolationStep.para: CAOS provides confidence percentage for leak location prediction.
Don full PPE (cryogenic gloves, face shield, apron).
With H2 detector in hand, approach suspected leak area.

listItem.para: Frost or ice formation (white/blue frost indicates liquid H2)
Venting or misting
Loose connections
Damaged seals or gaskets
Cracked or damaged lines

caution.warningAndCautionPara: Hydrogen flames are nearly INVISIBLE in daylight. Do NOT touch any surface that may be hot. Use thermal imaging camera if available.

isolationStep.para: Based on visual inspection and CAOS analysis:

listItem.para: If receptacle connection leak → Go to Step 6A
If valve seal leak → Go to Step 6B
If line/fitting leak → Go to Step 6C
If leak source unknown → Go to Step 6D
Verify ground refueling hose is disconnected (should have auto-disconnected on alarm)
Inspect receptacle coupling for damage, foreign object, or misalignment
Inspect receptacle seal for damage, contamination, or improper seating
Check receptacle mounting for looseness
Clean receptacle and seal per procedure 02-32-20-10-001
If receptacle damaged, replace per procedure 02-32-20-20-001
Perform pressure test per procedure 02-32-20-70-001 before return to service
Identify leaking valve (main, isolation, or check valve)
Verify valve is fully closed
Check valve actuator operation (may be partially open)
Depressurize and purge system completely
Remove and inspect valve per procedures 02-32-30-20-001
Replace valve seals or complete valve assembly
Reinstall and test per procedures 02-32-30-30-001 and 02-32-30-90-001
Locate exact leak point using H2 detector
If flexible hose: Inspect for cracks, abrasion, or flex fatigue
If fitting: Check for looseness, cross-threading, or gasket damage
If rigid line: Check for cracks, corrosion, or mechanical damage
Depressurize and purge system completely
Tighten loose fittings to specified torque
Replace damaged flexible hoses per procedure 02-32-40-50-001
Replace damaged rigid lines per procedures 02-32-40-60-001 and 02-32-40-70-001
Pressure and leak test per procedures 02-32-40-20-001 and 02-32-40-30-001
Depressurize and purge entire refueling system
Perform systematic helium leak test per procedure 02-32-20-80-001
Use mass spectrometer leak detector to locate leak
Once located, apply appropriate repair from Steps 6A, 6B, or 6C
If leak cannot be found, contact engineering support
Perform pressure test of repaired component/system at 5 bar for 30 seconds
Verify pressure drop ≤ 0.05 bar
Perform leak test using approved leak detection solution
Operate leak detection system functional test per procedure 02-32-50-80-001
Verify all H2 sensors reading 0 ppm with system pressurized (nitrogen)
Document repair in aircraft maintenance log
Update CAOS system with repair details and test results

isolationStep.para: Before returning aircraft to refueling service:

listItem.para: ALL pressure and leak tests PASSED
Leak detection system fully operational and calibrated
Grounding system tested and verified ≤ 3 milliohm
Ventilation system operational at 50+ ACH
All maintenance records complete and signed
H2 Certified Inspector signoff obtained
Safety briefing conducted for refueling crew

reasonForUpdate.simplePara: Initial release of troubleshooting procedure for H2 leak detection.
